sen.j: 元明天皇（げんめいてんのう、皇極天皇7年（661年） - 養老5年12月7日 (旧暦)（721年12月29日））は、奈良時代初代天皇で第43代の天皇で女帝（在位：慶雲4年7月17日 (旧暦)（707年8月18日） - 和銅8年9月2日 (旧暦)（715年10月3日））。
sen.e: Empress Genmei (661 – January 2, 722; reign: August 22, 707 – October 7, 715) was the forty-third imperial ruler (empress regnant) of Japan and the first imperial ruler in Nara period.

Empress Genmei (also known as Empress Genmyo) (661 – December 29, 721) was the first tenno (emperor) in the Nara period and the forty-third tenno (empress regnant) who reigned from August 18, 707 – October 3, 715).

I can hear brave men shooting arrows; I guess Minister Mononobe is preparing the target.

sen.j: 大夫之 鞆乃音為奈利 物部乃 大臣 楯立良思母 巻1-76
sen.e: Masurao no Tomo no Oto sunari Mononobe no Ohomahetsukimi Tate tatsu rashimo (Volume 1-76)
sen.cmt: 歌の漢字表記ですが、先に英語訳を出しているので、音訳をあてました。
sen.e: The original waka (in the "Manyoshu," volume 1-76) is written as follows: "大夫之 鞆乃音為奈利 物部乃 大臣 楯立良思母" (Masurao no tomo no oto sunari Mononobe no omaetsugimi tate tatsu rashimo).
The original waka (in the "Manyoshu," volume 1-76) is written as follows: "大夫之 鞆乃音為奈利 物部乃 大臣 楯立良思母" (Masurao no tomo no oto sunari Mononobe no omaetsugimi tate tatsu rashimo).

sen.j: 陵墓
sen.e: Mausoleum
Mausoleum
Mausoleum

sen.j: 奈良県奈良市奈良阪町にある奈保山東陵（なほやまのひがしのみささぎ）である。
sen.e: Her mausoleum is the Naho-yama no Higashi no Misasagi (east mausoleum on Naho-yama [Mt. Naho]) in Narazaka-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
Empress Genmei's mausoleum is the Nahoyama no higashi no misasagi (literally, Mt. Naho east mausoleum) in Narazaka-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 曖昧さ回避、形式。古墳名称参考：http://www.kunaicho.go.jp/ryobo/guide/043/index.html
sen.e: Empress Genmei's mausoleum is the Nahoyama no higashi no misasagi (literally, Mt. Naho east mausoleum) in Narazaka-cho, Nara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 山陵。
sen.e: The mausoleum has the shape of a hill.
sen.cmt: 通常「山稜」は「天皇の陵」の意味のようですが、ここは山状であることが重要と考え、その意味で訳出しています。
sen.e: The mausoleum has the shape of a hill.
The mausoleum has the shape of a hill.

sen.j: 円丘。
sen.e: It is an Enkyu (round mausoleum).
It is a knoll-like round tumulus.
It is a knoll-like round tumulus.

sen.j: 元明天皇は養老5年12月7日（721年12月29日）、崩御した。
sen.e: Empress Genmei passed away on January 2, 722.
Empress Genmei passed away on December 29, 721.
sen.cmt: 西暦日付の間違い。原文に西暦対応日付を補足のうえ再訳出。
sen.e: Empress Genmei passed away on December 29, 721.

sen.j: これにさきだって詔して「朕崩ずるの後、大和国添上郡蔵宝山雍良岑に竈を造り火葬し、他処に改むるなかれ」、「乃ち丘体鑿る事なく、山に就いて竈を作り棘を芟り場を開き即ち喪処とせよ、又其地は皆常葉の樹を植ゑ即ち刻字之碑を立てよ」。
sen.e: She ordered before her death, "After my death, construct a furnace in Sahoyama Yoranomine, Soekami-no-kori County, Yamato Province and cremate my body; don't do this in other places", and "Do not dig the hill; construct a furnace in the hill, cut prickles, open a ground and arrange it as a place for mourning; and plant ever green trees around the mausoleum and build a monument with carved letters on."

She ordered before her death as follows: "After my death, construct a furnace in Sahoyama yoranomine, Sounokami-no-kori County, Yamato Province, and cremate my body there; don't do this in any other places," and "Do not dig the hill; construct the furnace in the hill, cut thorns, open a ground and arrange it as a place for mourning; and plant ever green trees there and build a stone monument bearing an inscription."
sen.cmt: 記号の全角化、言い回し、形式、用語。「他処に改むるなかれ」は「改葬してはならない」とも読めますが、ここでは「他の場所で火葬してはならない」の解釈で訳出してあります。
sen.e: She ordered before her death as follows: "After my death, construct a furnace in Sahoyama yoranomine, Sounokami-no-kori County, Yamato Province, and cremate my body there; don't do this in any other places," and "Do not dig the hill; construct the furnace in the hill, cut thorns, open a ground and arrange it as a place for mourning; and plant ever green trees there and build a stone monument bearing an inscription."

sen.j: すなわち13日（722年1月4日）、喪儀を用いず椎山陵に葬った。
sen.e: Therefore, her body was buried in Nara Yama no Misasagi (mausoleum) without the funeral on January 8.
On January 4, 722, therefore, her body was buried in Narayama no misasagi (mausoleum) without the funeral.
sen.cmt: 西暦日付の間違い。対応西暦日付を原文に補足のうえ再訳出。参考：http://keisan.casio.jp/has10/SpecExec.cgi
sen.e: On January 4, 722, therefore, her body was buried in Narayama no misasagi (mausoleum) without the funeral.

sen.j: 陵号は「続日本紀」奉葬の条には「椎山陵」、天平勝宝4年閏3月の条には「直山陵」、遺詔に「蔵宝山雍良岑」とある。
sen.e: The name of the mausoleum is described 'Nara Yama no Misasagi' in 'Shoku Nihongi' (Chronicle of Japan Continued) the article of funerals; 'Nao Yama no Misasagi' in the article in leap March, 752; and 'Sahoyama Yoranomine' in her will.

The name of the mausoleum is recorded as follows: 'Narayama no misasagi' in an article on imperial funerals in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued); 'Naoyama no misasagi' in an article under the heading of leap March in the fourth year of the Tenpyo-shoho era; and 'Sahoyama yoranomine' in the Empress's own will.
sen.cmt: 記号の全角化、書名誤字、形式
sen.e: The name of the mausoleum is recorded as follows: 'Narayama no misasagi' in an article on imperial funerals in "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicles of Japan Continued); 'Naoyama no misasagi' in an article under the heading of leap March in the fourth year of the Tenpyo-shoho era; and 'Sahoyama yoranomine' in the Empress's own will.

sen.j: 延喜諸陵式には「奈良山東陵」とあり、兆域は「東西三町南北五町」とし、守戸五烟を配し、遠陵に列した。
sen.e: According to the Engi shoryo-shiki (codes and procedures on national rites for mausoleums), the name of the mausoleum was 'Nara-yama no Higashi no Misasagi' (east mausoleum on Nara-yama [Mt. Nara]),' the choiki (graveyard) being 'East and West Sancho, North and South Gocho,' arranged with Shuko Goen (a guard in charge of the protection of a mausoleum) and the mausoleum was counted as an Enryo (mausoleum of the Emperor's distant relative).

According to Engi shoryo-shiki (codes and procedures on national rites for mausoleums), the name of the mausoleum was 'Narayama no higashi no misasagi' (literally, Mt. Nara east mausoleum), the graveyard size being '3-cho (approximately 327.3 meters wide) in an east-west direction, and 5-cho (approximately 545.5 meters long) in a north-south direction,' which was provided with five Shuko households (the term Shuko refers to grave keepers) and the mausoleum was counted as an Enryo (a mausoleum of emperor or empress distantly related to the present Emperor).
sen.cmt: 記号の全角化、形式、表現、補足訳。守戸参考：http://yamatai.cside.com/katudou/kiroku225.htm 単位計算(Google電卓）： 3町 = 327.272727 メートル 5町 = 545.454545 メートル また、「烟」は煙のことでもありますが、ここでは世帯数を表す単位と思われ、そのように再訳出してあります。
sen.e: According to Engi shoryo-shiki (codes and procedures on national rites for mausoleums), the name of the mausoleum was 'Narayama no higashi no misasagi' (literally, Mt. Nara east mausoleum), the graveyard size being '3-cho (approximately 327.3 meters wide) in an east-west direction, and 5-cho (approximately 545.5 meters long) in a north-south direction,' which was provided with five Shuko households (the term Shuko refers to grave keepers) and the mausoleum was counted as an Enryo (a mausoleum of emperor or empress distantly related to the present Emperor).

sen.j: 中世、山陵の所在を逸した。
sen.e: In the medieval period, the place of the mausoleum was lost.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In medieval times, the whereabouts of the mausoleum were unknown.
In medieval times, the whereabouts of the mausoleum were unknown.

sen.j: 「前王廟陵記」は那富士墓の位置を擬し、「大和志」は大奈辺古墳を擬した。
sen.e: In 'Zen-o-byoro ki' (a book on the past emperor's mausoleums), it was estimated to be the place of Nafuji Haka (tomb), and in 'Yamatoshi', it was estimated to be the Onabe Tumulus.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The "Zen-o byoryo ki" (a study on the past emperors' mausoleums) supposed the location to be Nafuji Haka (tomb), whereas "Yamatoshi" (a topography of ancient Nara) supposed it to be Onabe-kofun Tumulus.
sen.cmt: 記号の全角化、書名、用語。「那富士墓」「大奈辺」の読み・詳細不明。 書物参考：http://dic.yahoo.co.jp/dsearch?enc=UTF-8&p=%E5%89%8D%E7%8E%8B&dtype=0&dname=0ss&stype=0&pagenum=1&index=111019600000
sen.e: The "Zen-o byoryo ki" (a study on the past emperors' mausoleums) supposed the location to be Nafuji Haka (tomb), whereas "Yamatoshi" (a topography of ancient Nara) supposed it to be Onabe-kofun Tumulus.

sen.j: 幕末の修陵の際に現陵に治定され、修補を加えた。
sen.e: At Shuryo (the restoration of the imperial tombs) at the end of Edo period, it was authorized as the present mausoleum, and as such it was restored.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At the restoration of the imperial tombs in the last years of the Edo period, the present mausoleum was authorized, thereby being restored.
At the restoration of the imperial tombs in the last years of the Edo period, the present mausoleum was authorized, thereby being restored.

sen.j: 慶応元年3月16日（1865年4月11日）、広橋右衛門督を遣わして竣工の状況を視し、奉幣した。
sen.e: On April 11, 1865, HIROHASHI Uemon-no-kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Guards) confirmed the completion and offered a wand of hemp and paper streamers to Shinto god.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On April 11, 1865, Hirohashi Uemon-no-kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Guards) was sent to the mausoleum, where he confirmed the completion of restoration and offered a heihaku (Shinto offering of hemp cloth, rope, paper etc., to a Shinto shrine deity).
sen.cmt: 原文に西暦日付を補足。補足訳。「広橋右衛門督」で右衛門督は役職名につき名字を大文字化していません。
sen.e: On April 11, 1865, Hirohashi Uemon-no-kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Guards) was sent to the mausoleum, where he confirmed the completion of restoration and offered a heihaku (Shinto offering of hemp cloth, rope, paper etc., to a Shinto shrine deity).

sen.j: 遺詔の「刻字之碑」は、中世、陵土の崩壊を見て田間に落ちた。
sen.e: In the medieval period, the 'monument with carved letters on' in her will fell between the fields due to the collapse of the mausoleum.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In medieval times, the 'monument bearing an inscription' built according to the Empress's will fell between rice fields due to the collapse of the mausoleum.
In medieval times, the 'monument bearing an inscription' built according to the Empress's will fell between rice fields due to the collapse of the mausoleum.

sen.j: これを発掘し、奈良春日社に安置した。
sen.e: Afterwards a monument was unearthed and enshrined in the Kasuga-sha Shrine in Nara.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Afterward, the monument was unearthed and enshrined in Kasuga-sha Shrine in Nara.
Afterward, the monument was unearthed and enshrined in Kasuga-sha Shrine in Nara.

sen.j: それを明和年間、藤貞幹（藤原貞幹、誤伝により藤井貞幹）が見て「東大寺要録」を参酌して元明天皇陵刻字之碑を考定した。
sen.e: During the Meiwa era, Sadamoto FUJII saw this, and taking 'Todaiji Yoroku' (the Digest Record of Todai-ji Temple) into consideration, he clarified this as the monument with carved letters on which stood by the mausoleum of the Empress Genmei.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During the Meiwa era, Teikan TO (also called Sadamoto FUJIWARA, or mistakenly Sadamoto FUJII) saw the monument, and taking "Todaiji Yoroku" (literally, Digest Record of Todai-ji Temple) into consideration, he identified it as the Empress Genmei's inscribed monument that used to stand at her mausoleum.
sen.cmt: 藤貞幹（とうていかん）または藤原貞幹の「藤井」姓は誤伝であると広く認識されているようです。http://kotobank.jp/word/藤貞幹 ここでは原文に補足のうえ再訳出しています。
sen.e: During the Meiwa era, Teikan TO (also called Sadamoto FUJIWARA, or mistakenly Sadamoto FUJII) saw the monument, and taking "Todaiji Yoroku" (literally, Digest Record of Todai-ji Temple) into consideration, he identified it as the Empress Genmei's inscribed monument that used to stand at her mausoleum.

sen.j: 文久年間の修陵の際にこれを陵側に移した。
sen.e: At the restoration during the Bunkyu era, the monument was transferred to the side of the mausoleum.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At the restoration during the Bunkyu era, the monument was transferred to the side of the mausoleum.
At the restoration during the Bunkyu era, the monument was transferred to the side of the mausoleum.

sen.j: 明治29年藤井の「奈保山御陵考」によって模造碑を作り、かたわらに建てた。
sen.e: In 1896, an imitation monument was built nearby, according to 'A Study of Naho-yama Goryo (imperial mausoleum of Naho-yama [Mt. Naho])'by FUJII.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1896, an imitation of the monument was built nearby, based on To's "Nahoyama goryo-ko" (literally, a study of imperial mausoleum of Mt. Naho).
sen.cmt: 言い回し、記号の全角化
sen.e: In 1896, an imitation of the monument was built nearby, based on To's "Nahoyama goryo-ko" (literally, a study of imperial mausoleum of Mt. Naho).
